lexicon_requests.reason: Unusual choice - 'stand' rather than more active verb for divine absence, implies intentional posture
Divine hiding verb - need semantic range of causative hiphil from עלם root
Arrogance as causal force - theological significance of pride terminology
Vivid 'burns after' - passionate hunting metaphor, need range of burning imagery
Grasping/greedy one - technical term for economic exploitation
Scorning/reviling with YHWH as direct object - shocking theological rebellion
Central wordplay verb (vv.4,13,15) - juridical 'seeking' with multiple subjects/objects
Dual meaning nose/anger in 'height of his nose' - physical/emotional metaphor
Prosperity verb - need range of חיל (strength/succeed/prosper)
Oppression/fraud - distinguish from מִרְמוֹת and אָלָה in triadic mouth imagery
Hapless/unfortunate victim - rare term, one of five victim vocabularies
Lion's lair/thicket - distinguish from den, cave, other predator habitats
Crushed/humbled - textual variant issue, subject ambiguity in v.10
Strong ones/mighty traps - ambiguous syntax in final predator image
Lowly/humble - textual variant with עניים, theological distinction
Terrifying - final cessation verb, need range of intimidation vocabulary
Mortal humanity vs elohim - theological contrast emphasizing earthly limitation

concordance_requests.purpose: Threefold heart quotation formula - wisdom literature technique of interior monologue
Lament opening formula - compare with v.1 'why stand aloof' rhetoric
Divine face-hiding - theodicy language matching v.1 and v.11
Divine non-seeking claim - first of three darash wordplay instances
Practical atheism statement - functional godlessness in wicked's schemes
False confidence formula - stability metaphor in wicked's self-assurance
Generational eternity formula - wicked's temporal claim vs God's eternality
Ambush sitting - beginning of extended predator metaphor sequence
Kingship formula - abrupt hymnic declaration answering theodicy
Imperative arising - urgent petition formula calling God to action
Orphan judgment - Torah covenant obligation for defenseless

figurative_requests.reason: Standing aloof - spatial metaphor for divine absence, unusual posture imagery | Vehicle: stand aloof | Related terms: standing aloof, stands aloof, stand far, stands far, standing far, stand distant, stands distant
Burning pursuit - passionate hunting metaphor with יִדְלַק intensity | Vehicle: burns | Related terms: burn, burning, blazes, blazing, inflames, inflamed, inflaming
Mouth fullness - somatic container metaphor for violence held ready | Vehicle: mouth full | Related terms: mouth filled, fills mouth, filled mouth
Under tongue - spatial metaphor for hidden readiness of violence | Vehicle: under tongue | Related terms: beneath tongue, under his tongue
Ambush sitting - predator posture in calculated violence metaphor | Vehicle: ambush | Related terms: ambushes, lying in wait, lies in wait, lurks, lurking
Lion in lair - explicit predator simile central to extended metaphor | Vehicle: lion | Related terms: lions, young lion, young lions, lioness
Net dragging - fishing imagery mixed with lion metaphor | Vehicle: net | Related terms: nets, snare, snares, trap, traps
Crouching posture - predator ready-to-spring imagery | Vehicle: crouch | Related terms: crouches, crouching, crouched, bows down, bowing down
Hidden face - divine absence parallel to v.1 spatial theology | Vehicle: hidden face | Related terms: hides face, hiding face, concealed face, conceals face
Lifted hand - power gesture of divine intervention | Vehicle: lift hand | Related terms: lifts hand, lifting hand, raised hand, raise hand, raises hand
Broken arm - political disarmament metaphor for destroyed power | Vehicle: break arm | Related terms: breaks arm, breaking arm, broken arm, shatter arm, shatters arm
Inclining ear - tender anthropomorphism of divine attention | Vehicle: incline ear | Related terms: inclines ear, inclining ear, bend ear, bends ear, bending ear

commentary_requests.reason: Opening double rhetorical question - how do commentators frame the theodicy problem of divine hiddenness?
Arrogance as causal force - traditional interpretation of ga'awah driving persecution
Boasting and reviling - how commentators parse the shocking direct scorn of YHWH
Practical atheism statement - classical exegesis of 'no God in all his schemes'
Prosperity paradox - traditional wrestling with apparent success of wicked
First heart quotation - how commentators frame interior monologue technique
Somatic violence imagery - traditional understanding of mouth/tongue as weapons
Beginning of predator metaphor - classical interpretation of ambush imagery
Lion simile with net mixing - how commentators handle mixed metaphors
Textual variants and subject ambiguity - traditional resolution of who crouches/falls
Second heart quotation mirroring v.1 - how commentators see wicked's theology echoing psalmist's complaint
Imperative cascade and divine names - traditional interpretation of urgent petition
Third heart quotation with darash wordplay - classical understanding of non-seeking claim
Theological hinge and reversal - how commentators interpret emphatic 'You DO see' turning point
Violent petition to break arm - traditional ethics of imprecation and power dismantling
Abrupt kingship declaration - how commentators explain sudden hymnic genre shift
Perfect tense confidence - classical interpretation of completed divine action
Enosh terminology and mortality contrast - traditional understanding of human limitation vs divine eternality

macro_questions: What is the significance of Psalm 10's connection to Psalm 9 as part of a broken acrostic, and how does this structural feature relate to the theme of broken/hidden divine order?
How does the three-fold 'says in his heart' formula (vv. 6, 11, 13) function in wisdom literature, and what does it reveal about the relationship between ideology and action?
What is the semantic range and usage of 'ani (poor/afflicted/lowly) in the Psalter, and how does Psalm 10's usage compare to prophetic social justice texts?
How does the predator/lion imagery in vv. 8-10 compare to other Ancient Near Eastern royal or military metaphors, and is there ironic reversal (the powerful acting like beasts)?
What is the theological significance of the verb ra'ah (see/look) in vv. 1, 11, 14—how does divine vision function in theodicy?
What does 'breaking the arm' (v. 15) signify in biblical political theology, and are there other texts where this metaphor appears?
How does the orphan (yatom) motif in vv. 14, 18 connect to Torah legislation (e.g., Exodus 22:22, Deuteronomy 10:18) and covenant identity?
What is the function of the nations ('goyim) in v. 16, and how does this relate to the psalm's concern with oppression—are the wicked identified with foreign powers or internal elites?
How does the phrase 'men of the earth' ('enosh min-ha'aretz) in v. 18 emphasize human mortality and temporal power versus divine eternality?
What is the rhetorical force of the shift from imperfect (future/modal) verbs in the petition section to perfect verbs in vv. 17-18, suggesting accomplished reality?
How does this psalm's theodicy—resolving divine hiddenness through assertion of divine kingship—compare to Job's treatment of the same problem?
What is the relationship between the wicked's 'prospering ways' (v. 5) and the concept of retributive justice elsewhere in Psalms—is there tension or development?
micro_questions: Why does the phrase אָמַר בְּלִבּוֹ ('says in his heart') appear exactly three times (vv.6,11,13), and what is the rhetorical progression across these interior quotations?
What is the syntactical relationship in v.4 between 'bal yidrosh' and 'ein elohim kol-mezimmotav' - is the latter a quotation, a description, or syntactically linked to the former?
How does the mixed predator imagery (lion in v.9 + net in v.9) function - are these compatible metaphors or deliberately jarring juxtapositions?
Why does v.16's kingship declaration use prophetic perfect אָבְדוּ ('nations have perished') - does this assert accomplished fact or prophetic certainty?
What is the significance of the five different terms for victims (ani, chelekah, naqi, yatom, dak) - do they represent distinct social categories or poetic variation?
How does the spatial theology (God stands afar v.1, judgments are high v.5, but God 'looks' v.14) resolve the theodicy problem?
What does the phrase אֱנוֹשׁ מִן־הָאָֽרֶץ ('man from/of the earth') in v.18 contribute theologically - is this about mortality, earthly power, or human limitation?
Why does the verb דרש appear in three strategic locations (vv.4,13,15) with different subjects and objects - what is the wordplay's function?
How does the emphatic fronted verb רָאִתָה in v.14 function grammatically and rhetorically - is this standard Hebrew emphasis or unusual?
What is the relationship between the 'mouth full' imagery (v.7) and the 'says in heart' quotations (vv.6,11,13) - interior vs exterior speech?
Why does v.10 have Kethiv/Qere variants, and how do these affect the interpretation of who is crushed/crouching?
How does the phrase 'breaking the arm' (v.15) function as political metaphor elsewhere in biblical literature - military, juridical, or symbolic disarmament?
What is the significance of the sudden genre shift to hymnic declaration in v.16 - does this interrupt the petition or resolve it?
Why does the psalmist use both YHWH and El in v.12 - is this poetic variation, theological emphasis, or liturgical formula?
How does the orphan motif (vv.14,18) connect to Torah legislation about widow/orphan, and does this invoke covenant obligations?
